He is born in 1940 .	1940 ! date ;
He is a product of the Cultural Revolution .	the Cultural Revolution ! thing ;
In fact he had to burn up an entire suitcase full of hundreds of poems and plays and stories at the start of the Cultural Revolution in fear of going to prison , and then in 1983 after being diagnosed with lung cancer , which had killed his father three years earlier and being convinced that he himself was going to die , he gets a kind of reprieve .	hundreds ! num ; the Cultural Revolution ! thing ; 1983 ! date ; three years earlier ! date ;
He gets a second chest X-ray , discovers that he does n't have lung cancer , recognizes that by virtue of the kinds of things that he is writing , his openness to Western literary ideas , that he is in political trouble again , and so he sets out on an extraordinary odyssey of some 15,000 kilometers , mostly on foot , which he takes through southwestern China .	second ! order ; Western ! national ; some 15,000 kilometers ! measure ; China ! country ;
He had survived , if you will , a death sentence , and now in that new freedom of the life in front of him , he takes to the road in the tradition of old Chinese poets and records what he sees , what he hears , the stories that he is told .	Chinese ! national ;
The book is filled with marvelous descriptions of the gorges through which he walks , the mountains that he climbs , indeed the book is called Soul Mountain , the mountain on which he hopes in some way or another to get in touch with his soul , his individual soul , as opposed to that mass kind of soul being enforced upon him by the Communist Chinese authorities , the social realism that the cadres would have him write in . He entered the Most Holy Place by using his own blood , not the blood of goats or young bulls .	end
He entered there and made us free from sin forever .	end

Christ offered himself through the eternal Spirit as a perfect sacrifice to God .	end
His blood will make us completely clean from the evil we have done .	end
It will give us clear consciences so that we can worship the living God .	end

It can be used only after that person 's death .	end

This means that not all of Abraham 's descendants are God 's true children .	end
Abraham 's true children are those who become God 's children because of the promise he made to Abraham .	end
Here is what God said in that promise : `` About this time next year I will come back , and Sarah will have a son . ''	end
And that is not all .	end
Rebecca also had sons , and they had the same father .	end
He is our father Isaac .	end
But before the two sons were born , God told Rebecca , `` The older son will serve the younger . ''	end
This was before the boys had done anything good or bad .	end
God said this before they were born so that the boy he wanted would be chosen because of God 's own plan .	end
He was chosen because he was the one God wanted to call , not because of anything the boys did .	end
As the Scriptures say , `` I loved Jacob , but I hated Esau . ''	end
So what does this mean ?	end
That God is not fair ?	end
We can not say that .	end
God said to Moses , `` I will show mercy to anyone I want to show mercy to .	end
I will show pity to anyone I choose . ''	end
So God will choose anyone he decides to show mercy to , and his choice does not depend on what people want or try to do .	end
In the Scriptures God says to Pharaoh : `` I made you king so that you could do this for me .	end
I wanted to show my power through you .	end
I wanted my name to be announced throughout the world . ''	end
So God shows mercy to those he wants to show mercy to and makes stubborn those he wants to make stubborn .	end
So one of you will ask me , `` If God controls what we do , why does he blame us for our sins ? ''	end
Do n't ask that .	end
You are only human and have no right to question God .	end
A clay jar does not question the one who made it .	end
It does not say , `` Why did you make me like this ? ''	end
The one who makes the jar can make anything he wants .	end
He uses the same clay to make different things .	end
He might make one thing for special purposes and another for daily use .	end
It is the same way with what God has done .	end
He wanted to show his anger and to let people see his power .	end
But he patiently endured those he was angry with -- people who were ready to be destroyed .	end
He waited with patience so that he could make known the riches of his glory to the people he has chosen to receive his mercy .	end
God has already prepared them to share his glory .	end
We are those people , the ones God chose not only from the Jews but also from those who are not Jews .	end
As the Scriptures say in the book of Hosea , `` The people who are not mine -- I will say they are my people .	end
And the people I did not love -- I will say they are the people I love . ''	end
And , `` Where God said in the past , ' You are not my people ' -- there they will be called children of the living God . ''	end
And Isaiah cries out about Israel : `` There are so many people of Israel , they are like the grains of sand by the sea .	end
But only a few of them will be saved .	end
Yes , the Lord will quickly finish judging the people on the earth . ''	end
It is just as Isaiah said : `` The Lord All - Powerful allowed some of our people to live .	end
If he had not done that , we would now be like Sodom , and we would be like Gomorrah . ''	end
So what does all this mean ?	end
It means that people who are not Jews were made right with God because of their faith , even though they were not trying to make themselves right .	end
And the people of Israel , who tried to make themselves right with God by following the law , did not succeed .	end
They failed because they tried to make themselves right by the things they did .	end
They did not trust in God to make them right .	end
They fell over the stone that makes people fall .	end
The Scriptures talk about that stone : `` Look , I put in Zion a stone that will make people stumble .	end
It is a rock that will make people fall .	end
But anyone who trusts in him will never be disappointed . ''	end
The Remaking of Linpien	Linpien ! country ;
Home of the Black Pearl Wax Apple	end
-LRB- Teng Sue - feng / photos by Jimmy Lin / tr. by Christopher MacDonald -RRB-	Teng Sue - feng ! person ; Jimmy Lin ! person ; Christopher MacDonald ! person ;
Even if the township of Linpien does n't have a monopoly on the cultivation of " black pearl " wax apples , it was orchards in the Linpien locality that earned black pearls their national renown .	Linpien ! country ; Linpien ! country ;
A little town formerly notorious for its ground subsidence problem , Linpien is now turning itself into one of Southern Taiwan 's premier tourist attractions .	Linpien ! country ; one ! num ; Southern Taiwan 's ! location ;
The impetus for this change has come chiefly from local historians , along with various voluntary groups .	end
Just before Christmas break , the rural township of Linpien , on the Pingtung Plain at the mouth of the Linpien river , held its first ever Wax Apple Festival .	Christmas ! thing ; Linpien ! country ; the Pingtung Plain ! location ; Linpien ! country ; first ! order ; Wax Apple Festival ! thing ;
The festival , in the town 's riverside park , was held to promote black pearl wax apples and celebrate the local volunteer spirit .	end
It was a scorching hot day , and heavily perspiring visitors were to be seen wandering among the stalls , lugging bags of wax apples and commenting on their remarkable sweetness .	end
" There 's a lot more than you 'd think to growing wax apples , " says local farmer Chen Sheng - tzung .	Chen Sheng - tzung ! person ;
" How you take care of the orchards , which equipment you use - it all has an affect on the shape and texture of the fruit . "	end
Prices for wax apples range widely , from around 3 pounds for NT$ 100 to NT$ 150 a pound .	3 pounds ! measure ; NT$ 100 ! money ; NT$ 150 ! money ;
Fruit that shows a hint of black through the red color of the skin fetches the best price .	end
Huang Wan - fu , whose family farms two hectares of orchard with more than 700 wax apple trees , and who has over 30 years ' experience as a fruit grower , says that while other parts of Pingtung County also grow wax apples , " Linpien stands out for its growing techniques , developed through trial and error by the growers themselves , and for vernalization rates of up to 90 % . "	Huang Wan - fu ! person ; two hectares ! measure ; more than 700 ! num ; 30 years ! date ; Pingtung County ! country ; Linpien ! country ; 90 % ! per ;
Ugly duckling no more	end
The wax apple is a tropical fruit originating from the Malay peninsula .	Malay ! national ;
The Dutch brought it to Taiwan from Java , in the 17th century , and it became commonly grown as a shade - giving tree .	Dutch ! national ; Taiwan ! country ; Java ! country ; the 17th century ! date ;
Old folk in the South remember when wax apples were " just something to munch on " - the kind of fruit that grew freely and that you could help yourself to .	South ! location ;
But wax apples have increased in value during the past 30 years , thanks to advances in the way that they are grown .	the past 30 years ! date ;
For example , the " bag - wrap " method was originally a way of protecting budding fruit from birds , but once it was introduced to Linpien , in around 1994 , farmers found it enabled them to grow more lustrous , shiny - looking wax apples , with less pesticide on the skin .	Linpien ! country ; 1994 ! date ;
The method soon caught on throughout the district .	end
Another popular technique involves covering the trees with black mosquito nets to improve yields .	end
This reduces the amount of sunlight reaching the trees , causing nutrients from the leaves and branches to be diverted into producing fruit .	end
The net - covered trees blossom earlier and produce more fruit .	end
As a result of this technique , black pearl wax apples are now available throughout most of the year .	most of the year ! date ;
The " black pearl " tag did n't originate in Linpien , but it was Linpien wax apples that made the variety famous and prompted the dramatic growth of its market .	Linpien ! country ; Linpien ! country ;
In 1983 the then - provincial governor Lee Teng - hui visited the town and praised the quality of its black pearl wax apples , so assuring the renown of the fruit .	1983 ! date ; Lee Teng - hui ! person ;
Subsequently , as president , Lee Teng - hui often gave gifts of black pearl wax apples to foreign dignitaries .	Lee Teng - hui ! person ;
Green hills	end
The success of black pearl wax apples gave Linpien a much - needed boost , bringing some of the younger generation back to the area to grow the fruit .	Linpien ! country ;
The credit for putting wax apples at the heart of the town 's revival and for mounting the Wax Apple Festival belongs with a group of volunteer workers - local people committed to the town 's regeneration .	the Wax Apple Festival ! thing ;
How does a small town like Linpien come to be home to such a well - organized volunteer effort , and just how did the volunteers set about giving their town a make - over ?	Linpien ! country ;
The story begins with the town 's riverside park .	end
The road linking the town 's main street with the riverside park , where locals like to stroll and chat at the beginning and end of the day , used to be overgrown and lined with trash .	end
Now , however , thanks to a coordinated effort involving volunteers , residents and landlords , the verges are planted with sunflowers and lantana , while a former mud patch , donated rent - free by its owner , has been converted into a carp - filled lotus pool .	end
The revamping of Linpien started eight or nine years ago , when schoolteacher Tsao Chi - hung - now a DPP deputy in the national legislature - along with fellow members of the Linpien Residents ' Democracy Association launched a program to sweep the streets and keep the riverbank clean .	Linpien ! country ; eight or nine years ago ! date ; Tsao Chi - hung ! person ; DPP ! org ; the Linpien Residents ' Democracy Association ! org ;
Wu Wu - ta , a plumber who runs the Democracy Association , says : " People were already doing their bit for the community over ten years ago , but not openly .	Wu Wu - ta ! person ; the Democracy Association ! org ; ten years ago ! date ;
They swept the streets before dawn because they did n't want people to see them and call them crazy . "	end
It was only three years ago , with the founding of the non-political Linpien Natural History Conservation Association , that residents began to publicly support the project .	three years ago ! date ; Linpien Natural History Conservation Association ! org ;
The flood - prone Linpien River has been dyked and dredged since the Japanese colonial era , but the bare concrete embankments never did much for the scenery .	Linpien River ! location ; Japanese ! national ;
In 1999 Tsao Chi - hung learned that the Water Conservancy Bureau was planning to renovate the flood defenses , and he proposed a scheme for " greenification " of the riverside area .	1999 Tsao Chi - hung ! date ; the Water Conservancy Bureau ! person ;
Objections were raised , however , with some pointing out that the site , if left untended , could easily get overgrown and become a breeding ground for snakes and vermin .	end
The issue was discussed and finally the Bureau agreed to let volunteers maintain the riverside area for two years .	Bureau ! org ; two years ! date ;
If the scheme did n't work out then the Bureau would concrete over the site as originally planned .	Bureau ! org ;
Following the lead of the conservation association and the Democracy Association , various volunteer groups in the district - including the senior citizens ' club , members of Tzu Chi Buddhist Foundation , the Presbyterian Church , and followers of the I - Kuan Tao sect - signed up to share responsibility for the riverside park , which was divided into 90 - meter - long plots for the purpose .	the Democracy Association ! org ; Tzu Chi Buddhist Foundation ! org ; the Presbyterian Church ! org ; I - Kuan Tao ! org ; 90 - meter ! measure ;
Turf was laid , flower beds appeared , and the embankment soon became a 1.2 km - long " green Great Wall . "	1.2 km ! measure ; Great Wall ! fact ;
Dreaming by the river	end
" You ca n't go about community work in a standoffish way , and you certainly ca n't operate effectively from behind the scenes - you have to be out there at the front of things .	end
When local people see teachers and doctors coming out to collect trash , they feel encouraged to join in , " says Chen Chin - chao , a dentist who chairs the Linpien Natural History Conservation Association .	Chen Chin - chao ! person ; the Linpien Natural History Conservation Association ! org ;
Chen frets about the way the media has focused the spotlight on him alone , when numerous other individuals are also involved , all chipping in what they can .	Chen ! person ;
" The biggest achievement is that the flowers have n't been stolen , " says Tsao Chi - hung .	Tsao Chi - hung ! person ;
" As more people volunteer to help , disruptive behavior becomes less and less likely . "	end
The riverside area used to be a teenage hangout , known for its drinking and fighting , but since greenification the town 's residents have been coming here to stroll and enjoy the scenery : green hills to the East , the sunset in the West , and the dreamy river alongside the park .	East ! location ; West ! location ;
" The more that people get involved the greater their sense of accomplishment , " says Tsao .	Tsao ! person ;
" It 's not just about tidying up the environment .	end
We also hope to foster the commercial interests of the community so as to bring practical benefits for people 's lives . "	end
This was the thinking behind Tsao 's gathering together of various groups for the Wax Apple Festival .	Tsao ! person ; the Wax Apple Festival ! thing ;
According to the archives , 400 years ago Linpien was a plains - aborigine settlement called " Fang - suo - she . "	400 years ago Linpien ! date ; Fang - suo - she ! country ;
In the middle of the 17th century the Ming dynasty loyalist Zheng Chenggong -LRB- also known as Koxinga -RRB- brought an influx of settlers to Taiwan from the Fujian and Guangdong regions of China .	the middle of the 17th century ! date ; Ming dynasty ! date ; Zheng Chenggong ! person ; Koxinga ! person ; Taiwan ! country ; Fujian ! country ; Guangdong ! country ; China ! country ;
Some of the Fang - suo - she aborigines stayed and intermarried with Chinese , while others moved away .	Fang - suo - she ! person ; Chinese ! national ;
The oldest recorded use of the name " Linpien " is on a stele , erected in 1762 , next to the town 's Sanshan King Temple .	Linpien ! country ; 1762 ! date ; Sanshan King Temple ! fact ;
The name , which means " beside the forest , " indicates that the early settlers must have had a tough time clearing land for their crops .	end
Moving to center - stage	end
In the past half century or more Linpien has concentrated on a series of different forms of produce , from rice , to bananas , to prawn and eel farming , to wax apples - today 's main crop .	the past half century ! date ; Linpien ! country ;
With Taiwan 's imminent accession to the WTO , the next big change could be just around the corner .	Taiwan ! country ; WTO ! org ;
For example , will wax apples lose their market to imported fruit ?	end
And what does Linpien have to offer that other districts in the county ca n't easily duplicate ?	Linpien ! country ;
Yang Hung - jen , a PhD student at National Taiwan University 's Graduate Institute of Sociology , came to Linpien a year ago to research his thesis on the renewal of the local community .	Yang Hung - jen ! person ; PhD ! art ; National Taiwan University 's Graduate Institute of Sociology ! org ; Linpien a year ago ! org ;
" I had come to what was said to be the worst county in Taiwan for factionalism and corruption , " says Yang , " a place where the ground had sunk as much as three meters due to subsidence .	Taiwan ! country ; Yang ! person ; three meters ! measure ;
But the contrast between that image and what I actually found here was quite something . "	end
For Yang , the way that those most active in the renewal effort routinely pass the credit to others is itself impressive .	Yang ! person ;
Linpien rose to prominence on the strength of its celebrated wax apples .	Linpien ! country ;
But can it now push its way to center - stage as a tourist attraction ?	end
Says Chen Chin - chao : " We ca n't yet say how things will turn out for Linpien .	Chen Chin - chao ! person ; Linpien ! country ;
But that 's not to be pessimistic about the town 's prospects ; it 's simply a case of not building castles in the air . "	end
Development of the long - promised Tapeng Bay Scenic Area is due to begin , and in 2003 the 2nd Southern Freeway will open .	Tapeng Bay Scenic Area ! location ; 2003 the 2nd Southern Freeway ! date ;
Will this bring more prosperity to the area ?	end
Construction of a bypass around the town has already boosted property values , but what other benefits may it bring ?	end
A golf course is mooted , but will that mean the loss of birdwatching zones and the mangrove woods ?	end
Can the wax apple orchards be adapted to serve as a setting for family outings ?	end
And can fish farms in the locality be converted to provide housing and accommodation , and a recreation alternative for visitors ?	end
Can this little town make an asset of its scenic location and historical roots to attract more visitors ?	end
Linpien used to be little more than a brief stop for travelers on their way to the seaside resort of Kenting , but now its residents are wondering if they can turn the town into a destination in its own right .	Linpien ! country ; Kenting ! country ;
Linpien Facts and Figures	Linpien ! country ;
Linpien Rural Township is in Pingtung County , located on the Pingtung Plain at the mouth of the Linpien River .	Linpien Rural Township ! country ; Pingtung County ! country ; the Pingtung Plain ! location ; the Linpien River ! location ;
It is adjacent to the planned Tapeng Bay Scenic Area , and marks the point where the 2nd Southern Freeway will terminate .	Tapeng Bay Scenic Area ! location ; the 2nd Southern Freeway ! fact ;
At 15.6 sq. km in area , it is the second smallest of Pingtung County 's 33 townships , and has a population of around 23,000 .	15.6 sq. km ! measure ; second ! order ; Pingtung County 's 33 ! country ; 23,000 ! num ;
Wax apples and aquaculture products are the main commodities , with betel nut and coconut also grown .	end
One - third of the township 's land is below sea level .	One - third ! num ;
Visitors are recommended to try the local seafood and also not to miss the opportunity for bird - watching among the nearby estuaries , wetlands and mangrove woods .	end
There are also cultural relics including traces of the original plains - aborigine inhabitants .	end
Linpien can be reached along Provincial Highway 17 .	Linpien ! country ; Provincial Highway 17 ! fact ;
The town has a railway station and can also be accessed by public and private bus services .	end

Tips for Getting through Middle Age	end
-LRB- Laura Li / photos by Hsueh Chi - kuang / tr. by Jonathan Barnard -RRB-	Laura Li ! person ; Hsueh Chi - kuang ! person ; Jonathan Barnard ! person ;
Middle age and the changes it brings are like a revolving door .	end
Many people peacefully go through it , growing wiser and losing their rough edges .	end
A minority do n't know whether to advance or retreat and get caught in it like a trap .	end
Middle age is a time where one wears more hats than at any other time in one 's life , when one 's responsibilities are heaviest .	end
As a result , the crises experienced by a minority of middle - aged people can involve a lot of other people , so their impact can not be overlooked .	end
Middle age , those years between 40 and 60 , is both the time of life of greatest glory and the time of life that 's easiest to overlook .	those years between 40 and 60 ! date ;
In comparison to youth or old age , the middle years are often thought of as the time when power , ability , wealth , and physical strength are all at or near their peak , so that one has no excuse for feeling melancholy .	end
Even if there are problems , it is commonly thought that one should be able to resolve them by oneself , notes Chiu Chia - li , director of the Hwo Chyuan Pastoral Counseling Center , who has worked on many middle - aged cases .	Chiu Chia - li ! person ; the Hwo Chyuan Pastoral Counseling Center ! org ;
Social bias makes many of the middle aged afraid to discuss their problems .	end
This is particularly the case for men , who generally find it difficult to talk about their feelings .	end
But by keeping everything inside , they may cause irreparable harm to their health .	end
In recent years cancer , sudden death and suicide have become all too common during middle age , which shows that the psychological problems of the middle - aged should not be overlooked .	end
How do you safely pass through the changes of the middle years ?	end
Here are a few suggestions :	end
1. Live well at every stage of life	1. ! num ;
Li Liang - che , a professor of psychology at National Chengchi University , looks at the question from the angle of developmental psychology .	Li Liang - che ! person ; National Chengchi University ! org ;
He points out that the path of life is continuous : everyone moves from infancy and childhood , to youth and middle age .	end
Smoothly passing through any period of life helps make getting through the next period easier .	end
In other words , the people most at risk during middle age are those who have had difficulties earlier in life .	end
Foreign research shows that those with high social and economic status and with ample financial resources bear up better during crisis and have more ways to get out of trouble .	end
Is it too late to start talking about these problems when you are already middle - aged ?	end
Chang Der - chung , an associate professor in the Department of Living Science at National Open University who worked at a counseling hotline for over a decade , argues that any step in the right direction is worthwhile , no matter when you start .	Chang Der - chung ! person ; Department of Living Science at National Open University ! org ; over a decade ! date ;
Middle - aged problems are rather predictable , and they 're not hard to avoid .	end
Are you worried that your marriage is growing stale ?	end
Then no matter how busy you are , you 've got to set aside some time to be with your spouse .	end
Are you worried about losing your job ?	end
Then start developing a second skill and get into the habit of saving and managing your money .	second ! order ;
Are you worried about how to care for your parents when they get old and sick ?	end
Then spend more time with them , and encourage them to get more exercise and take care of themselves .	end
There are so many things to be concerned about during middle age that you had better get an early start .	end
Otherwise , you 'll end up being overwhelmed .	end
2. Start over	2. ! num ;
In China it used to be said that middle age was the period when one was " heir to the ancient sages and the teacher of posterity . "	China ! country ;
But now times are changing so fast that perhaps the lessons of past experience are no longer suitable for solving today 's problems .	end
To assume a posture of superiority based on one 's seniority will make one despised .	end
Hence , it is necessary to cast aside one 's old self and start over .	end
Chiu notes that many middle - aged who have worked diligently for years to attain management positions look down on the younger generation for being reckless and disorganized , but they do n't realize that creativity and energy may be ready to explode from underneath these flaws .	Chiu ! person ;
Stuck in the past and full of bitterness , they may end up getting discarded onto the scrap heap of history .	end
With each new era , role models change .	end
Until the new role models have been established , it is important to maintain flexibility .	end
For instance , today 's middle - aged Chinese women are the first to have obtained advanced degrees and to have come in contact with the women 's liberation movement .	Chinese ! national ;
They set high expectations for themselves , but their disappointments are likewise large .	end
Many women are torn between conflicting desires : to be good homemakers like their mothers and to have successful careers like their fathers .	end
Their candles are burning at both ends , because they are trying to live up to two old role models rather than establishing a new one for themselves .	two ! num ;
Then there are men who insist upon being strict fathers and disciplinarians or staying at the same company until they retire .	end
And there are women who are determined to play the role of the traditional Chinese wife and mother .	Chinese ! national ;
Ignoring the changing times , they place tremendous pressure on themselves .	end
3. Turn the focus from outside to inside	3. ! num ;
Life is a process that moves from the " outward " to the " inward , " says Alice Lu , director of the International Family Life Education Center , getting to the heart of the matter .	Alice Lu ! person ; the International Family Life Education Center ! org ;
Lu explains that as children people yearn for the affection of their parents ; as adolescents they want the affirmation of their peers ; and as adults , they set their sights on educational qualifications , finding a good job , making money , marrying a good spouse and so forth .	Lu ! person ;
Everyone puts the emphasis on outward manifestations of success , and this emphasis on the glitter of outward achievement continues up to middle age .	end
" By middle age , people have gotten from the outside world just about all they can , " says Lu .	Lu ! person ;
" What they have n't attained yet they probably wo n't attain ever , so it 's not worth getting all worked up about it .	end
This is the time of life when the doubts set in . "	end
Many middle - aged people begin to ask themselves , " Is this really what I want ?	end
What has been the point of all my hard striving ? "	end
When the doubts come , some people continue trying to find answers from outside , thinking that everything would be fine if they could just change jobs or wives !	end
But then they rashly switch jobs or foolishly get involved in an affair only to find that they 've just made things worse .	end
" In middle age you start to listen to what 's going on inside , " says Lu .	Lu ! person ;
" It 's the time of life when you start to hone your skills at conversing with your soul . "	end
People ask themselves : Am I truly happy ?	end
Do I like the person I see in the mirror ?	end
Why ?	end
What dreams can I pursue ?	end
At this point , there is no longer any need to try to measure oneself against outside standards .	end
Instead it 's more important to accept oneself and attempt to find an inner balance .	end
" One need not compare one 's inner achievements with those of other people , " notes Chiu .	Chiu ! person ;
Everyone 's circumstances and personalities are different , and they place different expectations on themselves .	end
It 's not a matter of being better or worse than anyone else , and there 's no need to follow the currents of fashion .	end
Everyone is unique .	end
Morris Chang was in his fifties when he became an entrepreneur and founded Taiwan Semiconductor .	Morris Chang ! person ; Taiwan Semiconductor ! org ;
Many others at the same time in life have opted to take early retirement and find a guru in India , work as a volunteer , or do whatever else they want to do .	India ! country ;
In the modern age when people value different things , you can find a purely personal kind of happiness and success .	end
4. Realistically strive for one 's dreams	4. ! num ;
When focusing inward , many dreams that have long been discarded will end up floating to the surface .	end
At such times , one should remember to ask oneself three questions :	three ! num ;
" What do I want ? " " What can I do ? " And " What must I do and have ? "	end
Chang Der - chung reminds people to think clearly about their needs , and then think about the costs .	Chang Der - chung ! person ;
Will meeting these personal needs necessarily come into conflict with meeting one 's responsibilities ?	end
Is there some way that the two can be accomplished simultaneously ?	end
When facing problems at work in Taiwan , many people decide to change careers or even to pursue their fortunes in mainland China or Southeast Asia .	Taiwan ! country ; China ! country ; Southeast Asia ! location ;
Pursuing some dream of really making it big , many men use up their savings , leaving their wives as the sole source of family support and suffering loneliness in a foreign land .	end
There 's no right or wrong here , and there 's no way to guarantee a venture will be successful , but beforehand one must at least be realistic and prepare oneself psychologically for all possible outcomes , so that one wo n't suffer losses larger than one can bear .	end
" It is indeed the case that when one is young , one 's quiver is full of arrows and opportunities abound , so that one can shoot at will , " says Chang by way of analogy .	Chang ! person ;
" Once you get into middle age , you 've got to make every arrow count . "	end
Chang explains that everyone has dreams , and that continually working toward those dreams is an excellent method of relieving stress at any age .	Chang ! person ;
Middle - aged people have heavy burdens , and sometimes they may feel as if they are suffocating under them .	end
" But accomplishing a lot of little changes can bring about a big change . "	end
If you make an effort to do what you can , you will immediately find that your burdens have been lightened .	end
Chang cites this example : Say you hate being tied up by your work , and would like to go back to school .	Chang ! person ;
Why do n't you try a weekend class ?	end
Maybe that would help to alleviate your anxiety .	end
Or if you are a housewife , taking care of three generations and resentful that you ca n't go out and get the sense of accomplishment that comes with a full - time job , then maybe you could work as a volunteer in a community organization .	three ! num ;
This would both put you into contact with other people and help you gain a sense of accomplishment .	end
And you can help to sweat off your middle - aged anxieties by making a habit of regularly exercising .	end
What 's more , do n't worry too much about time being short .	end
Remember that most modern people live long lives that can be divided up into many stages .	end
In middle age , when you discover that your personal desires are coming into conflict with the demands of your family or society , decide which of your problems are the most urgent .	end
Do n't try to accomplish all of your dreams at once .	end
Maintain an unhurried frame of mind and peacefully wait for opportunities to present themselves .	end
5. Change your perspective	5. ! num ;
In middle age , one 's life is already half over , and one has already amply tasted of life 's fruits , both the bitter and the sweet .	end
" I am thankful for the bad times , for they have given me more insight into life and a better opportunity to understand myself , " says Lin Hung - kuei , an I - kuan Tao devotee , who has studied the Book of Changes and fengshui .	Lin Hung - kuei ! person ; the Book of Changes ! art ;

The Tanshui of illustrations is a place of unblemished beauty , a myth that remains unshakeable .	Tanshui ! country ;
In the 300 - plus years since its founding , this port town - formerly called Huwei , now Tanshui Township - has seen days of prosperity and has also been through a baptism of fire .	the 300 - plus years ! date ; Huwei ! country ; Tanshui Township ! country ;
What makes it special among the 309 urban and rural townships of Taiwan ?	309 ! num ; Taiwan ! country ;

How do they recall the past ?	end
And how do they see the future ?	end
" You want to know how Tanshui has changed ?	Tanshui ! country ;
I would say that the biggest change is that the old streets are gone . "	end
So declares Tu Hsiu - yuan , proprietor of the Hui Yuan Pharmacy , and also director of the Huwei Cultural and Historical Workshop .	Tu Hsiu - yuan ! person ; the Hui Yuan Pharmacy ! org ; the Huwei Cultural and Historical Workshop ! org ;
His pharmacy is located on what is now called Chungcheng Road , one of the oldest streets , which Tanshui natives still call Huwei Street .	Chungcheng Road ! location ; Tanshui ! country ; Huwei Street ! location ;

For the convenience of cars , the streets have been widened repeatedly .	end
In 1988 , the last train on the old Tanshui Line of the railroad chugged into history , taking that old slower pace of life with it .	1988 ! date ; Tanshui Line ! fact ;
In 1997 the Tanshui Line of the mass rapid transit system opened , bringing floods of visitors to the town .	1997 the Tanshui Line ! date ;

The golden age of Huwei	Huwei ! country ;
There are different explanations as to the origins of the word Huwei , the original name for Tanshui .	Huwei ! country ; Tanshui ! country ;
Some say it was a transliteration of the place name used by the indigenous people .	end
But others say it comes from a long - gone fishing practice , using a shi hu -LRB- " stone pool " -RRB- .	end
Early fishermen used stones to carve a long , narrow catchment -LRB- the so - called " pool " -RRB- in the sand , waiting for the tide to carry in fish which they could then easily scoop up .	end
Since the place now known as Tanshui was at the tail end -LRB- wei -RRB- of this stone pool , it came to be called Huwei .	Tanshui ! country ; Huwei ! country ;
Tanshui occupied an important place in the transport network connecting Taiwan to Southeast Asia .	Tanshui ! country ; Taiwan ! country ; Southeast Asia ! location ;
Even before the arrival of Westerners in Taiwan , Han Chinese often crossed over from China to Tanshui , which is relatively close to the mainland .	Westerners ! national ; Taiwan ! country ; Han Chinese ! national ; China ! country ; Tanshui ! country ;
Here they engaged in barter trade with the Pingpu -LRB- meaning " plains " -RRB- aborigines , with deer skins and sulphur being the most coveted products .	Pingpu ! national ;
As Western powers turned their eyes to Asia , Tanshui became strategically important .	Western ! national ; Asia ! location ; Tanshui ! country ;
In the 17th century , first the Spanish , and then the Dutch , built forts here as symbols of their claims to territorial control .	the 17th century ! date ; Spanish ! national ; Dutch ! national ;
In the mid-17th century , China took control of Taiwan , and closed Tanshui to international trade .	the mid-17th century ! date ; China ! country ; Taiwan ! country ; Tanshui ! country ;
Later , as a result of the Sino - French war of 1884 , Tanshui was again opened up to Western access .	Sino - French ! national ; 1884 ! date ; Tanshui ! country ; Western ! national ;
During Tanshui 's golden age , large and small boats were constantly coming and going in the harbor , and it was not unusual to see enormous steamships .	Tanshui ! country ;
In the latter part of the Qing dynasty , Tanshui was the largest port in Taiwan , and was the " customs headquarters , " also charged with overseeing port activities at Keelung , Tainan , and Kaohsiung .	the latter part of the Qing dynasty ! date ; Tanshui ! country ; Taiwan ! country ; Keelung ! country ; Tainan ! country ; Kaohsiung ! country ;
However , during the Japanese occupation , as a result of silting , and because the Japanese invested a huge effort in developing the port at Keelung , Tanshui faded in importance , never again to see the likes of its glory days .	Japanese ! national ; Japanese ! national ; Keelung ! country ; Tanshui ! country ;
Tanshui is a place of many historic sites , a place that invites reflection on things past .	Tanshui ! country ;
In the " foreign district , " a missionary named George Mackay established the first hospital for Western medicine in Taiwan ; it was here that in 1878 the first case of paragonimiasis in the world was diagnosed .	George Mackay ! person ; first ! order ; Western ! national ; Taiwan ! country ; 1878 ! date ; first ! order ;
The old church next to the hospital is a mecca for Tanshui painters .	Tanshui ! country ;
The schools , homes , and consulates in the foreign district - some long gone , some still standing - testify to the fact that this was a place of intensive interaction between Chinese and Western cultures .	Chinese ! national ; Western ! national ;
If you go up Sanmin Street , you will discover the head of an old and disused water pipe .	Sanmin Street ! location ;
This could be a relic left behind by one of the major Japanese infrastructure projects , the first tap water station .	Japanese ! national ; first ! order ;
Or you could walk instead next to the MRT station and see another first for Taiwan : the first seaplane landing area , also built in the Japanese occupation era .	the MRT station ! fact ; first ! order ; Taiwan ! country ; first ! order ; Japanese ! national ;
Or you could visit the venerable Tamkang Secondary School .	Tamkang Secondary School ! org ;

Under those circumstances , Tamkang Middle School became a cradle for the training of Taiwanese elites .	Tamkang Middle School ! org ; Taiwanese ! national ;
Gradually you will discover that Tanshui is a bookish place .	Tanshui ! country ;
This little town has everything from nursery schools to graduate schools .	end
During the reign of the Guangxu emperor of the Qing dynasty -LRB- which began in 1875 -RRB- , and prior to the beginning of the Japanese occupation in 1895 , Tanshui produced two successful candidates in the highest level military exam , one in the highest level civil exam , and countless successes in lower - level imperial exams .	Guangxu ! country ; the Qing dynasty ! date ; 1875 ! date ; Japanese ! national ; 1895 ! date ; Tanshui ! country ; two ! num ; one ! num ;
Even in modern times , the town has not passed up chances to embrace knowledge : When the idea of founding Tam - kang University in Tanshui was going to be abandoned because of a lack of land and money , local residents offered cheap land , donated money , and lobbied so that the university could set its roots in town .	Tam - kang University ! org ; Tanshui ! country ;
These historic sites are near the river , but do n't spend all your time there .	end
Do n't forget the Tatun Mountains , which shelter the town .	the Tatun Mountains ! location ;

These days you can take a local mini-bus .	end
In the mountains you will see the occasional terraced field grown over with weeds .	end

The Tanshui mystique	Tanshui ! country ;
The mountains are also filled with old stories .	end

Tanshui Facts and Figures	Tanshui ! country ;
Tanshui Township -LRB- also spelled Tamsui -RRB- is part of Taipei County .	Tanshui Township ! country ; Tamsui ! country ; Taipei County ! country ;

Powerful Tools for Biotechnology - Biochips	Powerful Tools for Biotechnology - Biochips ! art ;
-LRB- Chang Chiung - fang / photos by Hsueh Chi - kuang / tr. by Robert Taylor -RRB-	Chang Chiung - fang ! person ; Hsueh Chi - kuang ! person ; Robert Taylor ! person ;
The enterovirus detection biochip developed by DR. Chip Biotechnology takes only six hours to give hospitals the answer to whether a sample contains enterovirus , and if it is the deadly strain Entero 71 .	DR. Chip Biotechnology ! org ; only six hours ! time ;
Worldwide , biotechnology is a rising star of the industrial stage .	end
In Taiwan , in recent years the Ministry of Economic Affairs , the National Science Council and the National Health Research Institutes have been strongly pursuing " biochip " research programs .	Taiwan ! country ; the Ministry of Economic Affairs ! org ; the National Science Council ! org ; the National Health Research Institutes ! org ;
In the last two years , three biochip companies have also been set up in Taiwan .	the last two years ! date ; three ! num ; Taiwan ! country ;
Just what are biochips ?	end
What use are they to mankind ?	end
Why do so many people have such confidence in their future ?	end
What is the current state of this field in Taiwan ?	Taiwan ! country ;
And what are the prospects for future development ?	end
Let 's take a closer look .	end
In just a few years ' time , or a few decades , the following scenario could become a reality :	a few years ' ! date ; a few decades ! date ;
When you 're feeling under the weather , all you need to do is buy a diagnostic biochip from the chemist 's shop , put a drop of urine onto it , and you will find out what is wrong with you - a health check will be as easy as a pregnancy test today .	end
Everyone will carry with them a biochip bearing a record and analysis of their own DNA .	end
From it one will not only be able to see one 's own physical condition , but even to predict what diseases one will have in the future .	end
It will be like an ID card , needed when looking for work , buying insurance or even seeking a partner for love and marriage .	end
Laboratories will no longer need all kinds of large instruments , for all stages of their experiments will be carried out on little biochips , saving time , effort and money .	end
Today , the scenes outlined above may just seem like pipe dreams .	Today ! time ;
But these dreams could yet come true , and the key to that happening is those little biochips .	end
A dream come true ?	A dream come true ? ! art ;
Developments such as the sequencing of the human genome and the rapid development of genetic engineering have spawned biotechnology industries like bioinformatics , biomaterials and pharmaceutical engineering , which have emerged as the rising stars of 21st - century industry .	21st - century ! date ;
As part of the government 's efforts to promote the biotechnology industry in Taiwan , in July 1999 the Industrial Technology Research Institute -LRB- ITRI -RRB- set up the Biomedical Engineering Center -LRB- BMEC -RRB- to actively develop biomedical engineering technologies .	Taiwan ! country ; July 1999 the Industrial Technology Research Institute ! date ; ITRI ! org ; the Biomedical Engineering Center ! org ; BMEC ! org ;
Biochips are one of the core technologies in the field .	end
BMEC general director Dr. Johnsee Lee says that the ITRI 's four - year R&D program in biochip applications and technology is now in its second year .	BMEC ! org ; Johnsee Lee ! person ; ITRI ! org ; four - year ! date ; second year ! date ;
Its initial objectives are mainly focused on developing sensor chips to screen for infectious diseases , while later goals will be to develop technologies to test for genetic diseases and cancers .	end
As well as this new research establishment , in the two years since September 1998 three commercial companies have been set up in Taiwan to make biochips : U - Vision Biotech , Taiwan Genome Sciences and DR. Chip Biotechnology .	the two years ! date ; September 1998 three ! date ; Taiwan ! num ; U - Vision Biotech ! country ; Taiwan Genome Sciences ! org ; DR. Chip Biotechnology ! org ;
Of these , DR. Chip attracted much attention this year when it developed a chip to detect enteroviruses , a deadly epidemic of which has gripped Taiwan over the last two years .	DR. Chip ! org ; this year ! org ; Taiwan ! country ; the last two years ! date ;
Fever chips	Fever chips ! art ;
DR. Chip Bio-technology was set up in September 1998 .	DR. Chip Bio-technology ! org ; September 1998 ! date ;
Vice president Wang Shin - hwan states that the company successfully applied to the Ministry of Economic Affairs for funding to help it pursue a development program for enterovirus detection chips and test technology .	Wang Shin - hwan ! person ; the Ministry of Economic Affairs ! org ;
Today , the enterovirus chip is in the testing phase , and DR. Chip is collaborating with Taipei Veterans General Hospital to obtain samples with which to establish the accuracy of the chip .	DR. Chip ! org ; Taipei Veterans General Hospital ! org ;
What is so remarkable about the enterovirus detection chip when compared with traditional test methods ?	end
There are 68 known forms of non-polio enterovirus .	68 ! num ;
The detection chip does not simply determine whether a person is infected with enterovirus , but can also differentiate between different virus groups , for instance showing whether a sample contains the deadly Entero 71 virus , or Coxsackie A16 , which is easily confused with Entero 71 .	end
In addition , the chip and its accompanying PCR kit greatly reduce the time required for testing .	end
Wang Shin - hwan notes that traditional bacterial and viral cultures take seven to ten days to prepare , and even with the newer molecular biology testing techniques it takes three days to get a result .	Wang Shin - hwan ! person ; three days ! date ;
But DR. Chip has developed methods to reduce the sample preparation time , which enables a result to be obtained in only six hours when used in combination with their enterovirus chip .	DR. Chip ! org ; only six hours ! time ;
Furthermore , the initial results of joint trials by DR. Chip , Chang Gung University and National Cheng Kung University suggest that the chip is over a thousand times more sensitive than traditional test methods .	DR. Chip ! org ; Chang Gung University ! org ; National Cheng Kung University ! org ; thousand ! num ;
" In addition to enterovirus , we plan to develop chips to detect other infectious diseases such as hepatitis B , hepatitis C and HIV , " says Wang Shin - hwan .	Wang Shin - hwan ! person ;
Apart from the enterovirus chip , which is already at the testing stage , the ITRI 's Molecular Biomedical Technology Division is also conducting research and development on biochip applications and technology .	the ITRI 's Molecular Biomedical Technology Division ! org ;
Research program director Pan Chao - chi states that at present they are actively developing a " fever chip " with a wide range of applications .	Pan Chao - chi ! person ;
Pan explains that in clinical practice , the causes of fever are difficult to quickly diagnose .	end
A " fever chip " bearing the DNA of common fever - causing viruses and bacteria could be used to determine the cause of the fever and the type of pathogen involved would be a valuable tool .	end
However , Pan points out that because of the difficulties in substantially reducing the time needed for sample preparation , the usefulness of such a fever chip is still limited , so that it can not yet be widely promoted .	Pan ! person ;
Where the real money is	end
At present , most applications for biochips are in academic research and the development of new pharmaceutical drugs .	end
Demand for them is growing rapidly .	end
Johnsee Lee says that according to US market research estimates , the worldwide annual consumption of microarray chips is currently around 250,000 ; in two years this is expected to grow to 1.2 million .	Johnsee Lee ! person ; US ! country ; 250,000 ! num ; two years ! date ; 1.2 million ! num ;
Based on a market price per chip of US$ 1,000 , the size of the world market in biochips could grow to US$ 1.2 billion in 2003 , and to US$ 40 billion over the next decade .	US$ 1,000 ! money ; US$ 1.2 billion ! money ; 2003 ! date ; US$ 40 billion ! money ; the next decade ! date ;
Thus some people have set their sights on the biochip market , and believe that following Taiwan 's success in the semiconductor field , the island could go on to be a major center for contract manufacture of biochips .	Taiwan ! country ;
Be that as it may , the small number of biochip companies so far established in Taiwan still find their market in domestic research establishments and pharmaceuticals manufacturers .	Taiwan ! country ;
Although they are also actively developing overseas markets , what interests them most is not biochips per se , nor are they content merely to be contract manufacturers .	end
" The chips are only a tool , and the big money is not in chip sales .	end
What counts is the R&D behind them . "	end
Jerry Huang , executive vice president of U - Vision Biotech , reveals that U - Vision , which was set up in September 1999 , has signed a contract with the US company Zen - Bio to jointly develop human adipocyte cDNA microarray chips .	Jerry Huang ! person ; U - Vision Biotech ! org ; U - Vision ! org ; September 1999 ! date ; US ! country ; Zen - Bio ! org ;
Huang states that research in recent years has revealed that adipocytes -LRB- fat cells -RRB- are active regulators of the energy balance in the body , and play an important role in disorders such as obesity , diabetes , osteoporosis and cardiovascular disease .	Huang ! person ; recent years ! date ;
Thus it is hoped that research into human adipocytes can help in the search for drugs and other therapies to treat these disorders .	end
Apart from this , U - Vision is also conducting a one - year bacterial genome project , which aims to map the genome of a certain drug - resistant bacterium as a basis for developing new vaccines and drugs .	U - Vision ! org ; one - year ! date ;
Drug development	end
Taiwan Genome Sciences -LRB- TGS -RRB- , which was set up in November 1999 as a joint venture by the Uni-President Enterprises Group , Yuen Foong Yu and Tuntex Groups , only entered the biotechnology fray in April of this year .	Taiwan Genome Sciences ! org ; TGS ! org ; November 1999 ! date ; the Uni-President Enterprises Group ! org ; Yuen Foong Yu ! person ; Tuntex Groups ! org ; April of this year ! date ;
CEO Andrew Kuo says the investors came to the view that Taiwan needs to develop its biotechnology industries , and therefore they combined their resources to make a long - term investment in the field .	Andrew Kuo ! person ; Taiwan ! country ;
TGS 's strategy is to invest in a number of US genome research companies , and to sign technology transfer agreements and chip production contracts with them .	TGS ! org ; US ! country ;

Kuo states that at present , the number of known target sequences for disease - treating drugs is only around 500 , but as the human genome is mapped out this number can be expected to increase tenfold .	Kuo ! person ; 500 ! num ;
Currently , TGS has its sights set mainly on doing research into diseases which are especially prevalent in Asia , such as liver and stomach cancers .	TGS ! org ; Asia ! location ;
A chip revolution	A chip revolution ! art ;
However , the potential uses for biochips go far beyond the medical applications outlined above .	end
Dr. Johnsee Lee , who as well as heading up the Biomedical Engineering Center is also general director of Union Chemical Laboratories , a research institute under the ITRI umbrella , says that due to biochips ' advantages of miniaturization , parallelism , speed and the ability to reveal the " big picture , " they have a very wide range of applications .	Johnsee Lee ! person ; the Biomedical Engineering Center ! org ; Union Chemical Laboratories ! org ; ITRI ! org ;
They can not only be used as a research tool in biological , medical and pharmaceutical research and development , and as a clinical diagnostic tool for doing health checks , testing for infectious pathogens , screening blood and so on , but they can also find uses in such areas as defense applications , police forensic work , environmental testing and food testing .	end
Biochips come in two main types : the microfluidics chip or " lab - on - a - chip , " and the microarray chip or " DNA chip . "	end
Microfluidics chips bring together biotechnology , microelectronics , micromachining and other technologies to integrate the functions of multiple laboratory instruments onto a single chip in miniaturized form .	end
Meanwhile on microarray chips , biological molecules such as gene segments , oligonucleotides , proteins or antibodies are bound to the chip surface in an array of tiny spots , and a single chip may carry many tens of thousands of such spots .	end
BMEC researcher Pan Chao - chi uses the example of blood screening for a blood bank to illustrate the difference between the two kinds of chips .	BMEC ! org ; Pan Chao - chi ! person ;
To test a blood sample using a microarray chip , the sample must first go through many preparatory steps such as purification , nucleotide extraction , copying , amplification and labeling before being put onto the chip where the " hybridization " reaction takes place .	end
Finally , the results are analyzed using a detection system .	end
Hence these chips are only suitable for use in the laboratory .	end
In contrast , with a lab - on - a - chip system , all the laboratory preparation stages will be done on the chip itself , so that the user need only place a drop of blood directly onto the chip to obtain a result .	end
At present , microfluidics technology is not yet mature , and no such chips have been launched as commercial products anywhere .	end
But , says Pan Chao - chih : " This is the way future biochip development will go . "	Pan Chao - chih ! person ;
The poor man 's chip	The poor man 's chip ! art ;
Future prospects also seem infinite for microarray chips , which are already widely used in laboratories and research establishments .	end
Jerry Huang notes that DNA chips are an indispensable research tool in molecular biology .	Jerry Huang ! person ;
On one little biochip , tens of thousands of gene segments can be arranged to simultaneously detect the expression of tens of thousands of genes .	one ! num ; tens of thousands ! num ; tens of thousands ! num ;
In other words , whereas in the past researchers had to investigate each gene individually , today , using biochips , they can obtain test results for tens of thousands of genes at once .	tens of thousands ! num ;
In particular , biochips not only can speed the pace of research , but can also replace laboratory animals such as rats and rabbits in many experiments , with tests being carried out directly on human genes on the chip .	end
Thus as research tools biochips are not only convenient and quick , but also more humane .	end
Dr. Konan Peck , an assistant research fellow at Academia Sinica 's Institute of Biomedical Sciences -LRB- IBMS -RRB- , says that biochips need to be made more widely available as a molecular biology research tool .	Konan Peck ! person ; Academia Sinica 's Institute of Biomedical Sciences ! org ; IBMS ! org ;
With this in mind , Peck has developed nylon - based biochips which have been called " the poor man 's biochip , " since they cost a third less than glass chips .	Peck ! person ; a third ! num ;
Apart from the material itself being cheaper , the nylon chips use a visible - spectrum colorimetric system to display results , so that they can be read using an ordinary optical scanner , which costs 50 - 70 % less than using a special laser detector .	50 - 70 % ! per ;
The nylon membrane biochips currently produced by TGS and U - Vision Biotech are all derived from the technology developed by Konan Peck .	TGS ! org ; U - Vision Biotech ! org ; Konan Peck ! person ;
Cutting edge	Cutting edge ! art ;
Can Taiwan really repeat its success in the semiconductor industry , to become a major production center for biochips ?	Taiwan ! country ;
BMEC director Johnsee Lee observes that the level of scientific and technical know - how required for biochip production is very high , so that the opportunities for contract manufacture are limited .	BMEC ! org ; Johnsee Lee ! person ;
However , due to Taiwan 's early entry into biochip research and development , and the high state of development of its semiconductor industry , the island is well supplied with relevant technology and skills .	Taiwan ! country ;
Thus , says Lee , " Taiwan should have opportunities to enter this field not merely as a contract manufacturer . "	Lee ! person ; Taiwan ! country ;
The potential and importance of biochips is plain to see , but in this new , interdisciplinary industry , there are still many obstacles and difficulties to overcome .	end
Apart from the fact that the technology is not yet mature , and that generally accepted , mutually compatible international standards have not yet emerged , the biggest bottleneck for biochips at the moment is the many thousands of patents which have been taken out in the field , which limit the avenues available to each player .	end
" Because this area is a patents minefield , it 's impossible to create a product which from start to finish does n't infringe on anyone else 's patents , " says Johnsee Lee .	Johnsee Lee ! person ;
In his view , this problem may be resolved in the future by the exchange of patented technologies between players .	end
In other words , at this stage companies must actively carry out research and development , and obtain international patents , in order to have bargaining chips in future negotiations .	end
At present , the BMEC has over 10 patents pending in the areas of microfluidics biochips , chip surface processing technology and probe design and applications .	BMEC ! org ; 10 ! num ;
Pushing the envelope	end
Although at their present stage of development , biochips are already a great help to researchers , they are still far removed from ordinary people 's lives .	end
But one day they will play an important role in all our lives .	end
" Applications and commercialization are our goal , " says Johnsee Lee .	Johnsee Lee ! person ;
He says that only if research results are commercialized does research produce an economic payback .	end
Equally , to have a really broad market biochips need to go beyond the laboratory researcher , and into hospitals , clinics and homes , and to individual users .	end
Lee points out that before biochips will be worth commercializing , sample preparation needs to be made convenient , reading results must be simple and easy , the chips ' speed and accuracy must be high , and their cost must be low .	Lee ! person ;
He predicts that in one to two years , biochips will be suitable for use in supplemental tests , and after around three years for high - throughput screening ; in five years time it should be possible to develop them into general screening tools which will be as easy to use as the pregnancy test kits on the market today .	one to two years ! date ; around three years ! date ;
IBMS associate research fellow Konan Peck agrees that in the foreseeable future , diagnostic chips will enable everyone to learn their current state of health and know what diseases they may develop in the future .	IBMS ! org ; Konan Peck ! person ;
But in a situation where testing technology is ahead of medical treatment technology , the medical problems so discovered may not be treatable .	end
Mankind is always challenging his limits , and when , in the near future , biochips lift the veil of many diseases , the next challenge will have only just begun .	end

Thomas Lu is the doyen of the Chinese news media .	Thomas Lu ! person ; Chinese ! national ;
Still out on the journalistic front lines at 81 , this spry , forthright veteran has an immense zest for life .	81 ! date ;
At 78 , drawing on his astonishingly sharp memory , he completed his reminiscences and " record of emotional regrets . "	78 ! date ;
He is not only one of the " wonders " of Taiwan 's journalistic world , but is also recognized by those of his generation as a gentleman and a " good - looking man . "	Taiwan ! country ;
A person 's looks change with their age and their state of mind .	end
Many friends have told me I look better the older I get .	end
People do n't know that when I was young I had dreadful protruding teeth , but now not only do my teeth no longer show , but the lines of my face have also softened .	end
People who know me know that there have always been two great loves in my life : the news , and women .	two ! num ;
Now that I 'm in my 80s , looking back I think I can say I 've done alright in both respects , and I 've learnt that both reporting the news well , and finding favor with women , depend on your character and conduct .	80s ! date ;
Journalism is not just a profession , but should also be a vocation - you have to throw yourself fully into this infinitely broad field of endeavor .	end
Intellectually and spiritually , in work and in love , I have gained experience and fulfilment .	end
I have always remembered the encouragement which Mr. Yu Youren gave me as a young reporter .	Yu Youren ! person ;
He said that to be a fearless champion of social justice , as is expected of a journalist , the most important thing , apart from energy and vitality , is modesty .	end
You have to treat everybody the same , and not be overawed by the great and powerful .	end
A president or a street sweeper deserve the same respect as a human being , and should both be treated the same way .	end
Funnily enough , an unassuming attitude is also advantageous in relations with the opposite sex .	end
Chinese society is male dominated , and women are mostly regarded as having a subsidiary role .	Chinese ! national ;
In this kind of unfair situation , an upstanding man should cherish and respect women all the more .	end
A considerate attitude can be expressed in little things .	end
For instance , when you see that a hair has fallen onto a female friend 's shoulder , you should lightly pick it off for her , and throw it away or put it in your pocket .	end
If sincere , this kind of action is attractive in a man .	end
If a woman expresses her liking for you , then no matter whether she is pretty , or whether you find her attractive , you should respond in the same way , and with the same respect .	end
When I was a young reporter stationed in Europe , there was a British woman reporter who liked me very much .	Europe ! location ; British ! national ;
Once I was driving her somewhere to report a story when we had an accident , and she suffered some badly broken bones .	end
Although I was n't attracted to her in that way , I went to see her every day in hospital , and this left a deep impression on her of how considerate Chinese men can be .	Chinese ! national ;
Looking back at my life , I 've hardly had any really bad experiences in my relationships with women , and this is because just as in my professional life , I 've always maintained a self - critical attitude towards my emotions , and always tried to prevent myself acting like a male chauvinist .	end
Looks are something you are born with , but character is something you can work on , and it can outweigh your appearance .	end
Luo Jialun , one of the leading lights of the May Fourth Movement , is a famous example .	Luo Jialun ! person ; the May Fourth Movement ! thing ;
Luo was not good looking , and was even ridiculed as " looking like a cross between a pig , a dog and a bear . "	Luo ! person ;

I was imprisoned by both the Kuomintang and the Communists , and at times I might have been killed .	Kuomintang ! org ; Communists ! national ;

" 10,000 Rush to See Lu Executed " ?	10,000 ! num ; Lu ! person ;

it 's true that good looks can come from external grooming , wearing nice clothes , or wearing earrings ; and perhaps you can get other people 's attention by creating your own special look .	end

In September 2005 , a study report titled " Concern for Left - behind Children " had drawn wide public attention .	September 2005 ! date ; " Concern for Left - behind Children " ! art ;
While the situation of peasant workers in the city has repeatedly put society into question , the phenomenon of left - behind children in rural areas has gradually entered the view of the public .	end
Ye Jingzhong is the assistant dean of the College of Humanities and Development at China Agricultural University , and team leader of the Left - behind Children Task Force .	Ye Jingzhong ! person ; the College of Humanities and Development ! org ; China Agricultural University ! org ; the Left - behind Children Task Force ! org ;

According to the study by the task force , at present , the four main types of custody for left - behind children include single - parent custody , skip - generation custody , relative custody , and same - generation custody . In the study of left - behind children , many staff found out by surprise that the biological cycle of the farmers who work in the city , and the inculcation and upbringing cycle of their children , have formed two parallel lines that will never meet .	two ! num ;
Farmers who work in the city are generally a young workforce in their prime , while this is the period in which their children attend primary or junior high school .	end
Originally , they work in the city out of the hope that their children can receive a better education .	end
However , adolescent children need the loving care and guidance of their parents even more .	end
During this period , the absence of both or even one parent will create obstacles to the character development of the children .	end
This pair of unavoidable contradictions has made the problem of left - behind children in rural areas become more obvious .	end
